Card_1.description: Your old phone has slowed down and you need to buy a new one. Do you buy the latest, more expensive model or an older, cheaper one?

Card_2.description: You want to treat your friends on the occasion of your birthday. Do you take your friends out for a fancy dinner or to a Pizza place?

Card_3.description: Your phone bill for the month has arrived. You have the option to pay it now or pay next month with a late fee.

Card_4.description: There is a flash sale at your favorite store and you'd love a new pair of shoes.

Card_5.description: One side of your earphones has stopped working.  Do you buy a new pair or do you keep using it until both sides stop working?

Card_6.description: You received a ticket for parking your car incorrectly. You can pay in full now or pay half the fine with a late fee later.

Card_7.description: One of your friends invited you to the latest musical at the theatre for your birthday. Do you treat them with snacks during the intermission as a thank you, or split the bill?

Card_8.description: Your kitchen sink is broken. Do you repair it, knowing it will only last another month, or buy a new one?

Card_9.description: Your mother is in town for your birthday! Do you cook for her, or get a take-away?

Card_10.description: Your favorite author has released a new book! The book will be at a discount in a few months, when the store has its annual clearance sale.

Card_11.description: Your internet is cut off, because your bill is overdue. Do you pay it off or live without the internet for the rest of the month?

Card_12.description: A good thumb rule to use while budgeting, is the 50:30:20 rule. Whatever your income is, 50% of it is earmarked for necessary expenses like housing and food. 30% is for discretionary expenses like shopping and travel. And the remaining 20% goes straight towards saving - whether for your emergency fund, other financial goals, or even for retirement!
